title: Sion and the Soul Furnace Nerf Discussion.

embed.description: Welcome to the League of Legends Champion Spotlight, featuring Sion, the Undead Juggernaut. Dig into Sion's past here: Reborn - http://promo.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/reborn/ Sion, the Undead Juggernaut, revealed - http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/champion-reveal/sion-the-undead-juggernaut Dev Blog: Reimagining Sion - http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/champions-skins/champion-update/dev-blog-reimagining-sion Sion Q&A - http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/e3zHQ4A3-sion-champion-update-qa

body:
> Sion
> Soul Furnace [W] - Shield now 6/7/8/9/10% of max health and can be activated again after 3 seconds (changed from 10% at all ranks and 2 seconds)
> 

Sion's Soul Furnace is currently being tested for a Nerf. This nerf increases the lock-out duration for reactivation while additionally weaking Early-shield health.

Sion is rather strong right now, but I do not believe this to be an acceptable solution.  Among over a Hundred champions, Sion possesses an entirely Readable kit. His Decimating Smash creates a huge AoE Warning on the ground with a 1-2 Second Charge up, complete with additional sound and Animations for when it hits that 1 Second mark and can now knock you up.  It has a Range of 600

Sion's Soul Furnace is designed to be cast as a Follow up for Decimating Smash, and the two abilities naturally sync up together. Soul Furnace has a range of 550 and lasts 6 Seconds, can be detonated 2 seconds into the Shield charge for an early detonation, trading the Shield for Damage.
Similar to Decimating Smash, Soul Furnace has a distinct Animation and Charge up Sound, making it a clear and obvious threat.


You can literally see Sion's weaknesses in his Champion Spotlight. Before we saw him in the Professional Scene, people loved to bad mouth Sion and his absurdly easy counter-play.
What makes Sion Sion is how he's an unstoppable Juggernaut, something that takes time and commitment to take down, not someone you can simply ignore.  The additional Second added to Sion's Shield exploding Duration will Cripple Sion Jungling, as the Shield can only Sustain 1 Minion Auto per rank. Meaning you can take 2 Hit's at Rank 1 before it dies, and 3 at Rank 2, and 4 at rank 3.  This means that Until Sion has a level 2 Shield, he can't even use the Damage portion of the shield if he doesn't first CC the Monster he uses it on. 

That's current Sion, now Sion's going to need an additional Rank(level 3) just to clear his Gromp through his Shield.
We've not even spoken about the % nerf, and Sion has a low base health, so you're heavy-nerfing that early shield.  It is now useless at Rank 1. That's what you just did to it. There is no reason for Sion to take Soul Furnace, the move he wants to take to begin stacking Health, until level 3, and it's going to be a wasted point until level 4, or 5 if you take multiple points into any other Skill that may need them, like Decimating Smash.



There are plenty of other ways you can Nerf Sion.

You could change his Decimating Smash's Slow to increase per level, so it's not always 50%.
You could change the Damage on Sion's Shield to scaling rather than the Explosion Duration or Shield Health.
You could nerf the Range on Soul Furnace from 550 to 500.  I mean, Annie's spell and attack ranges are 650, so if Annie gets caught in Sion's Shield it's her fault right?  So why do we have to make the shield so much less.....Siony.

But what does everyone else think?  Do you find the shield abusive when you're fighting Sion? In lane or in Jungle?  Do you play Sion? What do you think of these changes?
Comment below, let everybody know.

While I understand your reasoning for why you think it an inappropriate nerf, I personally think that it is a fairly appropriate nerf.

The health scaling reduction at early levels it appropriate because it makes Sion weaker when he doesn't max W first. Just about every top lane Sion will max RQEW, and before his most recent changes he maxed REQW. His W was always really bad to max first because you didn't get a whole lot out of it because the % HP scaling was generally stronger than the rank-up rewards, and even then it was actually really strong.

The recast duration increase is appropriate because it still allows Sion to still have its current damage while still enabling his opponents to play around it. Even though Sion's Soul Furnace has plenty of readability, its short recast time allows you to still get plenty of reliable damage out.

These change I think are appropriate because they give Sion rank-up incentives to W that he didn't have before, especially in the top lane, while also leaving is amazing late-game completely untouched, and as long as Sion still has his late-game he's still going to be really good.

But Sion has to make it to lategame in order to be "really good" and if his opponent exploits his clearly defined weaknesses, then I seriously doubt he will remain a viable choice.  The reason Sion has such a high win rate is because the community as a whole does not know how to counter him.  Sion is basically Nasus, but everyone's at level 8 stuck watching the level 20 infinitely scaling champion farm over nine thousands stacks and one shot the whole map.  

And don't tell me you just "lol dodge the q, dummy" because you are part of the problem.  Sion is extremely weak at the beginning of the game.  He is a champion who wants to be a durable frontliner, but can't actually frontline anything because he is so fragile.  Literally as fragile as a mage without the range, mobility and damage inherent in balance to compensate for his weakness.  However, if you let him farm up a storm, over-extend in lane and dominate early team fights then he will become an incredible force to behold, a vision tarnished only by whiffing an R.  

Which leads me to my next point.  His skill-shots are not difficult to recognize, prepare for and react to so it isn't that bad having to only dodge a couple Q's, an E and that R.  The problem begins to manifest when you have an unending barrage of Q's, W's, E's and R's to worry about in any skirmish or team fight because it takes so goddamn long to kill him.  Good players will prevent that from happening by punishing his early game.  

That's Nasus 101.  These are simple strategies.  This is easy to think about.  In fact I would encourage you to try it out.  Next time you lane against Sion try to pick a champion that has stronger all-in or better range.  Jarvan, Fizz, Swain, Riven, Xin, Cho'Gath and Irelia to name a few.  Stick him repeatedly with whatever kind of engage or poke you have and you can dominate the lane.  If he ever gets a little too big for his britches, call your jungler or mid lane up to gank.  When you see him getting low on mana, entertain some of his poke to bait his engage.  Pre-6 Sion is a gigantic walking squishy punching bag waiting for you to shred him to pieces when he commits.  And when he commits he puts his team at risk.  A team with a fragile tank is a vulnerable team.  You can snowball so hard off of Sion by picking on him in early engagements, provided you and your team have the presence of mind to run away and slow him when he comes back to life.  If he decided to invest heavily into defensive runes and masteries, then you need not worry about his damage at all.  In fact you'll probably just regenerate as much naturally as long as you don't go ham catching his axe with your face because he will go OOM long before he can actually threaten your presence and it will only take a little bit longer to shoo him out of his farm or kill him trying to get it.  

Sion's damage was integral to his transition into a threat, but his balance was gutted when they started picking at him and I really hope they compensate for what they've done because it honestly feels like a little kid just ran right in front of me and kicked my pretty sand castle over leaving me with a mess of frustration, disappointment and lost hope.
